sections.summary: Allah is established as the **Originator** of the heavens and earth, having created angels with varying wings and adding to His creation as He wills. He is the sole source of **mercy**, which He unfolds for humanity without any power being able to withhold it.

The text notes the historical pattern of **prophetic rejection** and warns humanity not to be seduced by the **worldly life** or the **Tempter (Satan)** [530–531]. It distinguishes between those whose evil deeds are made attractive to them and those whom Allah **guides** according to His perfect knowledge.

Allah manifests His power through natural phenomena like the **winds** reviving dead land and the creation of **humanity** from dust and fluid. This biological development occurs according to His knowledge, which includes the precise record of an individual's lifespan and **takdir (destiny)**. He regulates the **sun and moon** and established two distinct seas, contrasting His absolute authority with the helplessness of **partners** who cannot hear or answer prayers [531–532].

Humanity is described as poor and in need of **Allah**, who is the **Rich** and Praiseworthy, capable of replacing mankind with a new creation. It affirms individual **accountability**, stating that no soul carries the burden of another and that **purification** is for the benefit of the soul.

Through parables of the **blind and seeing** or the **living and dead**, Allah illustrates the distinction between belief and disbelief. The Messenger is identified as a **warner** sent with the truth, echoing the mission of warners sent to every previous community.

Signs of **Divine Wisdom** are found in the diversity of nature’s colors and the fear of Allah felt by the **learned**. Those who recite the Book and establish **prayer** are promised a reward that will not fail, as the revelation confirms and completes previous **scriptures** [532–533].

Servants are categorized into three ranks based on their response to the **Book**, with the foremost in good deeds inheriting the **Gardens of Eden**. In contrast, disbelievers face eternal **Fire**, where their pleas for a **second chance** are rejected because they were given sufficient time to understand the truth.

Allah possesses knowledge of the **Unseen** and maintains the heavens and earth, preventing them from falling apart [533–534]. He challenges those who associate **partners** with Him to show any part of **creation** or any book that justifies their **delusions**.

The text rebukes the **arrogance** of those who swore they would be the most guided yet turned away when a warner arrived. It concludes by noting that while human actions deserve immediate punishment, Allah grants **respite** until a stated term out of His observance of His creatures.
